aboutOP:
OnomatoPedal

OnomatoPedal is an audiovisual playground inspired by the Japanese Onomatopoetic words and the music effects pedals of the world famous EarthQuaker Devices. All samples, music and code is available under the creative commons license below.
howToPlay:
How To Play

The main screen will display several EarthQuaker pedals each with a corresponding onomatopoetic word. Click on 'Shuffle Pedals' to get a new set of choices. Once you see a OnomatoPedal that you would like to explore, click on it. You will be taken to a page where you can play our music and add twelve sounds by tapping on your computer keyboard or mobile device.

On Desktop

You will be able to play a set of sounds with the following 12 keys on your computer keyboard: z, x, c, v, a, s, d, f, q, w, e, r.

On Mobile

Click to enter 'Play Mode', the musical track will start and you will see twelve drum pads. You can play along with the music or pause the music to just play the pads.
freeSamplePack:
Free Sample Pack

On the desktop version, you will see a button to download the sample pack files. This will download a zip file containing the twelve samples plus the music track.

The samples and music is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-ShareAlike 4.0 International License.
credits:
Created by PatternBased

Design and Code by Siori Kitajima
Fork this project on github

Music production/curation by Joseph Minadeo

Music by Puffy Shapes, Low in the Sky, Gnosotros, Microstructures, Full Blown Kirk, Taka Tozawa, Billy Dixon, Corey Farrow, Patrick McNulty, Kevin Carr, Joe Golden, Corey Haren, Cory Juba, Jamie Stillman, Ben Vehorn, Michael Tolan, Krista Tortora, Josh Weatherspoon, Jack Randall, Brett Lashua, Ralph Carney, Karl Vorndran, Curt Brown, Jacob Trombetta, Jeff France, Joseph Minadeo, Delia Nakamura and Hainbach

Recorded and produced in Tokyo, Kyoto, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Berlin, Akron and Morongo Valley

OnomatoPedal, The album is available at the PatternBased Bandcamp.

Pedal circuits by Jamie Stillman

Pedal graphics by Matt Horak and Jamie Stillman

Japanese Onomatope description by An Illustrated Dictionary of Japanese Onomatopoetic Expressions by Taro Gomi, published by Kodansha Ltd,

Made with amazing tools including Paper.js, Howler.js, Visual Studio Code, Github, VCV Rack, Bfxr, NI Polyplex, Ableton, OP-1, Arturia, Omnisphere, Output, Fractal Bits and TTSMP3

Thank you Julie Robbins, Jamie Stillman, Luke Zollinger, Geoff Crowe, Uri Garcia, Anna Blumenthal and everyone at EarthQuaker Devices, Yugo Kitajima, Laura Apetroaei, Szigeti Lorand, Admiral Potato, Chiho Okada, Corabelle and Orlando.
modalMessage:
Play with the following 12 keys on your computer keyboard:
Z,X,C,V,A,S,D,F,Q,W,E,R
bannerEqdMerch:
ONOMATOPEDAL ME
OP Original Merch

Through July 2, 2020, 100% of the merch profits will be donated to Black Lives Matter.
versionTwoBody:
OnomatoPedal Ver 2.0

PatternBased and EarthQuaker Devices are seeking artists to contribute to a potential version 2.0 of OnomatoPedal. If you are a visual artist versed in code, a coding artist versed in visuals/shaders/fluid-sims/SVG/etc, get in touch.
